8.2.17  12:03 am   Hello! Couple questions for you... When writing out the script for your videos, do you also make notes for yourself about stuff like vocal inflections, tone, delivery, timing, etc?  

     Also, is there any improvisation involved in the score/background music (I think you said before you do that part last, but do you fully chart it out before recording it?)

     or improvisation in the main jingles?

     For example in 'hi, i'm steve'... for the mailwoman's variation of the "that's the way i like to live my life" jingle there's a little keyboard fill that comes right after "live my life". Was that fill entirely written out note-by-note beforehand?

8.1.17  10:18 pm   I saw a Paul Simon interview online where he was talking about the song Still Crazy After All These Years (unfinished at the time of the interview)... and he said something that I thought was very interesting. He said he wanted to go to either a C or C# in the bridge because he hadn't used them in the melody of the verse. His quote was that "the listener will not ever consciously  say 'those are two new notes I haven't heard". But, in fact, it will be refreshing to the ear." He also compared the same thing to comedy, saying that you can establish a comedic pattern, but then once the pattern is recognized you have to alter it. Just curious what your thoughts are on this?

      Do you think you do something kind of similar to this in writing songs or making videos?

8.1.17  8:23 pm   I think that the reason people aren't noticing more inclusions in journals is because of a design discrepancy that I'm not too sure how to fix... a lot of people are used to this Scrolling Content Feed like on twitter or tumblr or facebook where people are almost being trained to smash the refresh button and develop a tunnel vision for the top most post at all times, so much that they lose all periphery in their content consumption habits... It's kinda tragic, but it's one of the reasons why I really like your site. I think some users are trying to force you into some kind of "Genre" of creator (whether it be your site or music or etc) so much that people seem to believe that you're trying to be irreverent, but all you do is just... *is*. Words kinda fail me there, and that's okay I think. People are looking at the pages that update "top-down" (as in "updates as you finish content" such as the music, videos, and most of the time the questions page) a nd autom atically assume that it applies to Literally Everything In The Entire World Ever All The Time Always when your notebook stuff is clearly labeled with a very definite Date Of Time, emphasizing Creation Chronology, but your site didn't exist forever so you come to this design dilemma for the content that was made Pre-Website: Emphasize Creation Chronology, or Update Chronology? Well, it's not really a dilemma, but it's more that people are too busy trying to see you in their terms as a creator so much that they're missing out on the actually new content. Something about not seeing the forest for the trees?
8.1.17  8:15 pm   What motivated you to change from short/medium sized videos to medium/long videos?

8.1.17  7:33 pm   I was reading about how musicians use to get different effects and sounds from their instruments 'back in the day.' Some pretty cool stuff. In You Really Got Me, Ray Davies apparently used a razor blade to splice the speaker cone in his amp and poked pins into the cone. In Street Fighting Man, Keith Richards got an electric-guitar sound from an acoustic by using a tape cassette to record and overdub the parts and by playing right up to the mic. Link Wray used to poke holes in his speaker cone with pencils to get that fuzzy tone. You had all sorts of experimentation with reel to reel tape recorders to get echos and other weird effects. Lots of old blues guitarists would turn the gain and volume all the way up on lo-fi amps to the point of nearly blowing out the speakers to get their sounds. Sam Phillips (who produced a lot of those 50's rockabilly/rock 'n' roll records with Sun Records) would re-feed the playback from the recorder to the head, adjusti ng the s pace between the heads, tape speed and other stuff to make crazy echo and delay effects.... Today with all sorts of effects pedals, built in effects on amplifiers, digital recording sofwares where you can alter the sounds in so many different ways, do you think that these "proto-effects" or these old recording techniques are obsolete?

     When you're recording do you ever experiment with any of this type of stuff to create effects or different sounds, or do you it all on the computer, effects pedals, etc.?

8.1.17  1:49 pm   For the notebook/reality pages have you considered putting the upload date along with the date you recorded/wrote the thing?

      Maybe that would help clear up all of the "why haven't you updated this!?!" questions... or maybe put a little footnote or header saying that the date is when it was made not uploaded, or maybe color-code the entries by year or something like that? For people that are maybe going on this page for the first time and they click on reality or notebook they see the top entries as being from 2016 and (unless they read through this question page) they would think that those pages haven't been updated since then...i think its awesome that you have this question page and your email...that gives you a way to connect/communicate with your fans in a way that many other artists dont. But with that openness comes all the demands and criticisms and trolls (unfortunately). Just remember that when people request stuff they do it because theyre fans wh o love your work. BTW you're the man, Bill. Love all your content and your music has made a huge impact on me.
